G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Newton District Court.

See *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, individuals have a duty to act with reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
See *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694,.support_reasoning: The opinion assumes the existence of a negligence framework (duty, breach, causation, damages) and focuses its analysis entirely on the plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation. The court explicitly declines to decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiffs, so it does not affirm or articulate the general Massachusetts principle that individuals must act with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm. Thus, this case does not serve as authority for the broad duty proposition cited.
See *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694,.relevant_excerpt:
The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care).
...
Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.

See *Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.raw_text: See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996).
See *Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.proposition: Defendant’s negligent actions and omissions were a proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
See *Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
See *Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence expressly agrees that the facts would not warrant a jury finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is, it concludes proximate cause is lacking. This directly contradicts the claimed proposition that the defendant’s negligent actions and omissions were a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries, so the case does not support that proposition for this citation.
See *Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randol.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

See *Adams v. Dunhill*, 64 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: See *Adams v. Dunhill*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 215, 217 (2005) (negligence liability may arise where foreseeable consequences of one's actions result in injury to the plaintiff).
See *Adams v. Dunhill*, 64 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Though the dog did not make physical contact with Plaintiff, Defendant’s negligence directly caused Plaintiff to swerve and fall while trying to avoid what she reasonably perceived as an imminent risk of being attacked.
See *Adams v. Dunhill*, 64 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns personal jurisdiction, res judicata, and comity in the context of foreign divorce judgments and post-divorce economic claims. It does not address negligence, proximate cause, or liability for injuries arising from evasive action to avoid a perceived imminent attack by a dog or any other instrumentality. Therefore, it provides no authority for the stated negligence proposition and the citation is inapposite to that issue.
See *Adams v. Dunhill*, 64 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 34, as amended through St. 1982, c. 642, § 1, authorizes the award of alimony or the allocation of marital property “[u]pon divorce or upon a complaint in an action brought at any time after a divorce, whether such a divorce has been adjudged in this commonwealth or another jurisdiction . . . , provided there is personal jurisdiction over both parties.” Accordingly, to determine whether the wife’s claims may lawfully be adjudicated in Massachusetts, we apply the two-step inquiry set forth in Good Hope Indus., Inc. v. Ryder Scott Co., 378 Mass. 1, 5-6 (1979).

See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.raw_text: See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 745, 756 (1984) (foreseeability is integral to establishing negligence).
See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s unreasonable failure to control his dog.
See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case addresses negligence and emphasizes foreseeability generally, but it involves police officers’ failure to remove an intoxicated motorist from the road, not a private dog owner’s failure to control a dog. While the opinion clearly states that foreseeable harm to motorists from a drunk driver can create a duty and proximate cause, it does not deal with animal control or dog-related injuries. Thus it supports the broader principle that foreseeability is integral to negligence, but not specifically that a plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable consequence of a defendant’s failure to control a dog.
See *Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that there is a special relationship between a police officer who negligently fails to remove an intoxicated motorist from the highway, and a member of the public who suffers injury as a result of that failure. The statutes which establish police responsibilities in such circumstances evidence a legislative intent to protect both intoxicated persons and other users of the highway. As to the most crucial factor — foreseeability — the calamitous consequences to the victims of accidents caused by drunken driving are all too predictable.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 155.proposition: G.L. c. 140, § 155 – Massachusetts leash law and strict liability for dog-related injuries, relevant to understanding Defendant’s duty.

King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.raw_text: King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658 (1977)
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.proposition: King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658 (1977) – Negligence arising from breach of statutory duties.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.support_reasoning: The opinion analyzes and reshapes the common-law tort duty of landlords regarding common areas, holding that a landlord owes tenants (and their visitors) a general, continuing duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas. It does not ground liability in a breach of a statutory duty; statutes like G.L. c. 186, § 19 are mentioned only as consistent with the court’s common-law ruling. Therefore, the case supports landlord negligence based on common-law duty, not negligence per se or negligence arising from breach of statutory duties.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.relevant_excerpt: “We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors… The trial judge was thus correct in charging the jury as he did.… An indication of legislative policy consistent with our ruling may be found in G. L. c. 186, § 19… [T]he tenant or any person rightfully on said premises injured as a result of the failure to correct said unsafe condition… shall have a right of action in tort against the landlord…”

Ward v. Greene, 267 Mass. 596 (1929).proposition: Ward v. Greene, 267 Mass. 596 (1929) – Lawful actions taken to avoid perceived danger may still support a negligence claim.
Ward v. Greene, 267 Mass. 596 (1929).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns foreclosure sales, the duties of a mortgagee under a power of sale, and the termination of the equity of redemption; it does not involve negligence, danger, or a party taking lawful actions to avoid perceived danger. The holding focuses on whether a foreclosure sale was conducted in good faith and whether the right to redeem survived the auction, not on standards of negligence related to self-protective conduct. Therefore, it does not support the stated negligence proposition.
Ward v. Greene, 267 Mass. 596 (1929).relevant_excerpt: "The bank was required to conduct the sale in good faith with reasonable regard to the interests of the owners of the equity and junior lienors. But it did not appear that the dominant purpose of the bank was to secure the property for itself at its own price, nor that it desired a sale at an unfair price. It was concerned with securing payment of its loan. This is not enough to show bad faith or disregard of its obligations as mortgagee."

G.L. 272, \u00a7 80H.proposition: G.L. 272, § 80H – Animal control obligations under Massachusetts law.
